Risk Management Program Requirements

Section 112(r) of the CAA requires EPA to publish rules and guidance for chemical accident prevention. The rules promulgating the list of regulated substances (published January 31, 1994) and the Risk Management Program provisions (published June 20. 1996) are found at 40 CFR Part 68. The Risk Management Program contains three elements: a hazard assessment, a prevention program and an emergency response program. The entire program is to be described and documented in a Risk Management Plan (RMP), which is submitted to EPA.



The RMP for the Kalamazoo Water System Pumping Station # 1 (WPS# l) includes the following main topics that fulfill the information requirements for the EPA Risk Management Plan.



?    Executive Summary

?    General Applicability to 40 CFR Part 68;

?    Management System

?    Hazard Assessment;

?    Prevention Program;

?    Emergency Response

?    Risk Management Plan Registration; and

?    Appendices with miscellaneous related information.



A Risk Management Plan is required for WPS #1 because it is a stationary source (a facility) with more than a threshold quantity (2500 lbs) of a regulated substance (chlorine) in a process (chlorine vacuum educator feed system), as determined under section 68.115. In compliance with the regulations, the plan was first submitted in June 18, 1999 and, again, pursuant to EPA regulations was updated in June 16, 2004, in June 2009, and again in June 2014. This report represents the June 2019 update.



The Risk Management Program regulations also define the activities that the City of Kalamazoo must undertake to identify and minimize the risks posed by chlorine in covered processes. Specifically, EPA defined three program levels to ensure that individual chemical processes are subject to appropriate requirements based on the size of the process and the associated risks.



WPS #1 falls under the Program 2 requirements because the operation is not eligible for Program 1 due to the locatio

n of the facility in proximity to residences. hospital, and commercial establishments; the process is not subject to MIOSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements because there are no Public Services employees stationed at this location; and the process does not fall under any of the ten specified worth American Industrial Classification System codes included in the regulations.



At a scheduled PSM inspection of WPS #1 on March 19, 2009, MIOSHA enforcement staff determined that the WPS #1 was not subject to the PSM requirements due to the lack of full time staffing at the station. Therefore, by default, the operation of WPS#1 falls under Part 68 Program 2 requirements that imposes streamlined prevention program requirements, as well as additional hazard assessment, management, and emergency response requirements.





The Kalamazoo Department of Public Services has a management structure to oversee responsibility for the development, implementation and integration of the risk management program elements and have provided documentation in this plan of the names of people or positions and have defined the lines of authority through an organizational chart.



Since the WPS #1 chlorination system is a Program 2 process, this RMP includes a worst-case release analysis (catastrophic release from a one 1-ton cylinder) and an alternative release scenario analysis (3/16" gasket failure in a one ton cylinder). This information will be used to coordinate emergency response activities with local first responders in case either of these scenarios should occur.



In the past five years, there have been no accidental releases of chlorine at WPS #1 that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



However, in order to prepare for a possible release of chlorine gas from WPS #1, the emergency response activities have been coordinated with th

e City of Kalamazoo Public Safety Department (first responders) and the Kalamazoo County Office of Emergency Management HazMat Team.



The Department's Prevention Program is based on the basic elements that are the foundation of sound prevention practices - safety information, hazard review, operating procedures, training, maintenance, compliance audits, and accident investigation. For example, the department' s hazard review of the WPS #1 chlorination system is built on the safety information compiled in this report; utilizing the results of the hazard review to

revise and update operating and maintenance procedures and training in these procedures.



In addition, an Emergency Response Plan has been developed for the site. This plan, which has been submitted to the Kalamazoo County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), contains measures that Water System staff can take to alert employees to a release, personal protective equipment, how to distinguish between an incidental release and a significant release, and many other elements. WPS #1 is included in the Kalamazoo County Emergency Hazmat Response Plan and identified as Facility ID 12521. The staff receives emergency response training in response to an on-site release and for incident command practices. In addition, staff, along with outside agencies and consultants, has conducted two tabletop exercises to discuss area-wide emergency response procedures should a catastrophic release of chlorine occur.



Finally, the following occurrences will result in the revision and submittal of a revised RMP on a more frequent basis than the regulatory requirement of every 5 years:

?    Information on reportable chemical accidents within six months

?    Changes to the emergency contact information
